awd_titl_txt: RCN: Applied Privacy Research Coordination Network: An Industry-Academic Network to Transition Promising Privacy Research to Practice
awd_abstract_narration:
The Future of Privacy Forum Education and Innovation Foundation (FPF EIF) is establishing the Applied Privacy Research Coordination Network (Applied Privacy RCN) to support the transition of academic privacy research to commercial practice by providing ongoing, structured networking and opportunities for privacy scholars to meet industry leaders involved in their research areas and develop working partnerships. The Applied Privacy RCN will promote new knowledge, techniques and practices to better protect individual privacy. Cutting-edge privacy research can lead to cutting-edge commercial applications -- but only if privacy researchers and corporate privacy leaders are connected. This RCN offers targeted mechanisms to bridge the gap between scholarship and industry practice. The RCN will bring researchers together with privacy leaders from the world's top companies and innovators across business sectors, engage the world's largest privacy professional association and top industry trade associations, and expand reach to international audiences and markets. The RCN will accelerate industry action and help transition promising privacy research to real-world practice where personal information is handled in a manner that respects individual privacy.

To accomplish these goals, the RCN will organize academic participation in and presentations to monthly meetings of FPF industry-specific working groups and direct communications and introductions with FPF EIF's corporate members. It will organize a series of presentations of academic researchers to industry practitioners at the annual in-person meeting of the FPF Advisory Board, the global summit conference of the International Association of Privacy Professionals (IAPP), a new event at the FPF EIF's marquee annual event, Privacy Papers for Policymakers, and at an international workshop designed to build international collaborations of privacy researchers and industry. The events will attract graduate and doctoral student participants, support junior scholar publishing opportunities, and develop internship opportunities. Through its strategies and methods, the RCN furthers the development of a community of privacy researchers and builds the wider field of practice.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Led by the Future of Privacy Forum (FPF) Education and Innovation Foundation, the Applied Privacy Research Coordination Network (Applied Privacy RCN) generated multichannel opportunities for academic researchers to present and discuss research in privacy, data sharing, machine learning, and privacy enhancing technology to corporate stakeholders. Designed to support the transition of academic privacy research to commercial practice, the Applied Privacy RCN facilitated interactions among industry and academic researchers for advancing discussions and collaborative relationships. The Applied Privacy RCN underscored the imperative to facilitate academic-industry relationships in privacy-related research across disciplines, sectors, and technologies and the need for future work to heighten commitment (and pathways) to corporate-academic data sharing.

Under the Applied Privacy RCN, FPF designed and carried out more than 35 focused webinars, conferences, and small-group discussions, hosting academic researchers as speakers and attendees in major events, conferences, and working group meetings. FPF used its extensive connection to industry (200+ corporate members) to identify areas of interest such as augmented and virtual reality, autonomous vehicles, facial recognition, and research data sharing and sought out academics in these areas. This targeted approach ensured meaningful engagement. In the course of the grant, over 300 academic researchers and corporate stakeholders were introduced to each other through RCN-sponsored events, with a subset beginning independent discussions, explorations, and collaborations with each other. 

Major activities under the Applied Privacy RCN included: 1) exposure of academics in FPF's high-profile annual event, "Privacy Papers for Policymakers," inviting privacy scholars and authors to submit scholarship for consideration by a committee of reviewers and judges from the FPF Advisory Board. Fifteen papers were selected as winners plus three student papers, providing opportunities for these authors to be showcased and interact with industry professionals; 2) sponsorship and participation in professional conferences and events promoting the RCN including at the IAPP Global Privacy Summits and the Privacy Engineering Practice and Respect (PEPR) conferences; 3) hosting of a series of RCN-focused webinars on a variety of topics such as autonomous vehicles, facial recognition, robotic process automation, virtual reality, and smart cities; 4) hosting of and participation in international events with industry and academia, including "Privacy & Pandemics: Responsible Uses of Technology and Health Data During Times of Crisis: An International Tech and Data Conference" in collaboration with NSF (NSF Award #2035358), Duke Sanford School of Public Policy, and SFI/Science Foundation of Ireland ADAPT Research Centre, Dublin City University, and "The Independent and Effective DPO: Legal and Policy Perspectives" organized by FPF and Dublin City University; 5) hosting of a virtual symposium taking an in-depth look at the role of biometrics and privacy in the COVID-19 era, in partnership with  Carnegie Mellon University's CyLab Security and Privacy Institute and Highmark Health; 6) updates to the Applied Privacy RCN Portal (https://fpf.org/research-coordination-network/), including issues of the Privacy Scholarship Reporter; 7) co-hosting of a four-part Responsible Research Data Sharing Dinner Series bringing together over 150 corporate stakeholders and academic researchers to tackle the issue of data sharing for research, and initial development of a resulting Playbook for Responsible Data Sharing for Research (planned for spring 2022 publication); and 8) ongoing facilitated interactions with FPF communities, including subject-specific FPF Working Group meetings, monthly FPF Privacy Landscape calls, FPF Corporate Member briefings, FPF Advisory Board meetings, and FPF PhD staff participation in industry-academic settings.

In sum, by engaging over 300 researchers and practitioners, the Applied Privacy RCN increased industry recognition of academic privacy research, gave academics opportunities to promote their research and to collaborate with corporations, and identified corporate-academic data sharing as a key issue needing further attention. While new collaborations formed under the Applied Privacy RCN will continue their respective trajectories, this RCN demonstrated the importance of facilitated exposure, dialogue, and relationship building between academic researchers and industry as an impactful means to help transition privacy research and knowledge to real-world practice.
